choices.text: Galactose and fructose in the blood.
Maltose, sucrose, and lactose in the stool

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with a genetic anomaly affecting the activity of disaccharidases produced by the intestinal epithelial cells. These enzymes are responsible for the digestion of various disaccharides into monosaccharides, which can then be absorbed into the bloodstream. After consuming a meal consisting of milk and oatmeal, both of which contain disaccharides, which of the following would you expect to find in higher levels in this patient compared to a healthy individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Maltose, sucrose, and lactose in the stool  

 

Option C:

 

Due to the reduced activity of intestinal disaccharidases, this patient would have difficulty breaking down disaccharides into their absorbable monosaccharide forms. As a result, disaccharides like maltose (from oatmeal), sucrose (common table sugar), and lactose (from milk) would be less likely to be digested and absorbed, leading to their increased presence in the stool.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Galactose and fructose in the blood would be lower, not higher, because these monosaccharides result from the digestion of lactose and sucrose, respectively, which is impaired in this patient.

 

Option B: Starch in the stool would not necessarily be higher because starch digestion begins with salivary and pancreatic amylase, not disaccharidases.

 

Option D: Glycogen in the muscles would be unaffected directly by disaccharidase activity as it is dependent on the uptake of glucose from the blood, which would be reduced due to the malabsorption of its precursor disaccharides.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Starch: digested to small oligosaccharides and maltose but produce lower quantity of glucose due to deficiency of the brush border disaccharidases, which include sucrase and lactase. So, Sucrose and lactose will not be cleaved and will accumulate.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 538, 599

questions.text: A patient with a long-standing history of type I diabetes mellitus has been diligently adhering to insulin therapy, yet consistently records fasting and postprandial blood glucose levels that exceed the normal range. To assist in better glucose regulation, a dietician suggests an increased intake of dietary fiber. Among the Option listed below, which type of dietary fiber is most beneficial for managing blood glucose levels in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pectin

 

Option D:

 

Pectin is a soluble dietary fiber that forms viscous gels when mixed with water in the digestive tract. This gel formation has several beneficial effects for blood glucose management:

  • Delays gastric emptying
  • Slows glucose absorption in the small intestine
  • Reduces postprandial glucose spikes
  • Improves overall glycemic control

 

These properties make pectin particularly valuable for patients with diabetes who need to manage blood glucose levels.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Cellulose: These are polymers of glucose. It retains water in feces; promotes peristalsis and increases bowel action. It is the starting material for production of fibres, celluloids, nitrocellulose, and plastics.

 

Option B: Hemicellulose: These include pentoses, hexoses and uronic acid, which retains water in feces and increases bile acid excretion.

 

Option C: Lignin: They are aromatic alcohols with hypocholesterolemic, antioxidant action and also increases bile acid excretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dietary fibers are classified as soluble (pectin, gums, mucilages) or insoluble (cellulose, hemicellulose, lignin). Soluble fibers like pectin form viscous gels that slow digestion and absorption of carbohydrates, making them particularly beneficial for blood glucose management in diabetes. Pectin is found in fruits (especially apples, citrus fruits), berries, and some vegetables. Insoluble fibers primarily improve bowel health and regularity without significantly affecting blood glucose levels directly.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: P 156-158.

questions.text: A biochemistry laboratory technician observes the crystalline structures shown in the provided image after performing an osazone test to identify reducing sugars in a patient's urine. Which sugar is most likely responsible for the formation of these specific osazone crystals?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lactosazone

 

Option D:

 

The crystals in the image have a morphology that resembles rosette-like formations, which are typically characteristic of lactosazone. Lactosazone crystals form distinct rosette or "hedgehog" shapes when lactose reacts with phenylhydrazine during the osazone test, making them distinguishable from other sugar osazones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Maltosazone: Maltosazone crystals tend to have a "pom-pom" or "sunflower" shape with radial striations, which does not match the crystals in the image.

 

 

Option B. Gout: The term 'gout' refers to a clinical condition characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals, not related to the sugar-derived osazone crystals seen in the image.

 

Option C. Glucosazone: Glucosazone typically forms as needle-like clusters, which while somewhat similar, are generally less defined and rosette-like compared to lactosazone crystals. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The osazone test is to distinguish between different reducing sugars based on the characteristic crystalline structures they form when reacted with phenylhydrazine.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 583.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who has recently experienced several episodes of diarrhea was advised by her general practitioner to consume fructans like inulin, which serve as prebiotics due to their non-digestibility. What is the primary reason for the resistance of such carbohydrates to digestion in the upper gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Beta configuration of anomeric C2

 

This is the primary reason fructans like inulin resist digestion in the upper GI tract:

Fructans consist of fructose molecules linked together, and in fructose (unlike glucose), the anomeric carbon is C2 rather than C1. The beta configuration at this anomeric C2 carbon creates β glycosidic linkages between fructose units in inulin. Human digestive enzymes in the intestine (like amylase, maltase, sucrase, etc.) are specific for hydrolyzing α-glycosidic bonds, particularly those found in starches and common disaccharides. These enzymes cannot break the β-glycosidic linkages at the anomeric C2 carbon in fructans, making these carbohydrates non-digestible in the upper GI tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta configuration of anomeric C1 - This is incorrect because in fructose molecules, C1 is not the anomeric carbon. In fructose, the anomeric carbon is C2, which makes this answer choice fundamentally incorrect for describing fructans.

 

Option B. Low pH of the stomach - While the acidic environment of the stomach can affect some carbohydrates, this is not the primary reason for fructans' resistance to digestion. Many digestible carbohydrates also pass through the same acidic environment without becoming resistant to digestion. The specific glycosidic linkages, not stomach acidity, determine digestibility.

 

Option D. Presence of α-Glycosidic linkage - This is incorrect because Inulin contain β-glycosidic linkages, not α-glycosidic linkages. α-Glycosidic linkages are actually digestible by human enzymes (like amylase, maltase), so their presence would make a carbohydrate more digestible, not less.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key mechanism that makes fructans like inulin function as effective prebiotics is their resistance to digestion in the upper GI tract due to the beta configuration at the anomeric C2 carbon. This structural feature creates β-glycosidic linkages between fructose units that human digestive enzymes cannot break down. As a result, these carbohydrates pass intact to the lower intestine where they selectively stimulate the growth of beneficial bacteria, particularly Bifidobacteria and Lactobacilli.

questions.text: In considering the chemical structure of lactose as it pertains to its digestion and metabolism within the human body, it is essential to identify the specific type of glycosidic bond present. Which of the following best describes the glycosidic linkage found in the disaccharide lactose?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) β (1 -> 4)

 

Option B:

 

Lactose, the main carbohydrate found in milk, consists of one molecule of glucose and one molecule of galactose joined by a β(1 -> 4) glycosidic bond. The configuration of this bond is significant as it requires the enzyme lactase for hydrolysis, which cleaves the bond to release the two monosaccharides for absorption.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: An α (1 -> 4) glycosidic bond is found in maltose, not lactose.

 

Option C: An α (1 -> 6) linkage is characteristic of the branching point in lactulose, glycogen and starch, not found in lactose.

 

Option D: β (1 -> 6) - It is typically seen in Isomaltose and structural polysaccharides like cellulose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e p 77.

choices.text: Antibiotic that contains amino sugar is tetracycline
Amino group is donated by Glutamine.

questions.text: Amino sugars are a crucial component in various biological structures and functions. When assessing the characteristics of amino sugars, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Antibiotic that contains amino sugar is tetracycline

 

Option C:


Tetracycline does not contain an amino sugar; instead, it is a broad-spectrum antibiotic composed of four cyclic rings.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Glucosamine is indeed an amino sugar, commonly found in the exoskeleton of crustaceans and in the human body as part of the structure of glycosaminoglycans.

 

Option B: The precursor for the synthesis of most amino sugars is indeed glucose, which undergoes enzymatic transformation to introduce an amino group.

 

Option D: In the biosynthesis of amino sugars, the amino group is typically donated by the amino acid glutamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important amino sugars are:

  • Glucosamine
  • Galactosamine  
  • Mannosamine.

 

Glucose is the precursor of Amino Sugar.
Amino group is denoted by Glutamine.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with chronic congestive heart failure (CCF) has been prescribed digoxin, which enhances cardiac contractility and rhythm. Digoxin comprises a sugar moiety and a non-sugar (aglycone) component linked via an oxygen atom. What is the chemical classification of digoxin based on this structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glycoside.

 

Option A:

 

Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside.

 

Glycosides contain a sugar and a non-sugar component (aglycone) linked together by O-Glycosidic linkage.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Glycoprotein: When the carbohydrate chains are attached to a polypeptide chain it is called a proteoglycan and if the carbohydrate content is less than 10%, it is generally named as a glycoprotein.

 

Option C: Oligosaccharide: Further addition of sugar groups to a Trisaccharide produces tetrasaccharides, pentasaccharides and so on, known as oligosaccharides.

 

Option D: Polysaccharide: Polymerized products of many monosaccharide units.

 

They may be:

 

  1. Homoglycans (single kind of monosaccharides, e.g. starch, glycogen and cellulose)
  2. Heteroglycans (two or more different monosaccharides, e.g. hyaluronic acid, chondroitin sulphate).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The chemical structure of digoxin is a cardiac glycoside, which has therapeutic effects in heart failure by increasing the force of cardiac muscle contraction.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 7/e: 75.

questions.text: A one-month-old infant exhibits severe abdominal distension, pain, and diarrhea after breastfeeding. Urinalysis indicates the presence of a reducing sugar. The subsequent test yields the crystal formation shown in the image. What type of crystals are these?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lactosazone

 

Option C:

 

The picture shows ‘Osazone crystals’- lactosazone crystals (powder puff shaped).

 

Lactosuria denotes excessive excretion of lactose in urine seen in ‘Lactose Intolerance’, where the undigested lactose is absorbed by pinocytosis into systemic circulation to get excreted through urine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Glucosazone and B: Fructosazone: The differences in glucose, fructose and mannose are dependent on the first and second carbon atoms, and when the Osazone is formed these differences are masked. Hence, these 3 sugars will produce the same needle-shaped crystals arranged like sheaves of corn or a broom.

 

 

Option D: Maltosazone: sunflower or petal shaped.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lactose intolerance or lactase deficiency in an infant, diagnosed by the presence of lactosazone crystals in the urine following the ingestion of lactose from breast milk.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 7/e: 73-74.

questions.text: A clinician evaluates a patient with decreased visual acuity and diagnoses cataracts, a condition characterized by clouding of the lens. The development of cataracts can be influenced by various metabolic factors, including the accumulation of certain substances within the lens. Among the following, which substance's accumulation is most commonly associated with the formation of cataracts?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sugar alcohol.

 

Option D:

 

The accumulation of sugar alcohols, particularly sorbitol, in the lens of the eye contributes to cataract formation. Sorbitol, produced from glucose by the enzyme aldose reductase, can accumulate in the lens under hyperglycemic conditions, leading to osmotic stress and lens opacification.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: While high blood glucose levels are a risk factor for cataract development, glucose itself does not accumulate in the lens to the extent that it directly causes cataracts. Instead, its conversion to sorbitol is the main issue.

 

Option B: Galactose can lead to cataracts, primarily in conditions like galactosemia, where there's an inability to metabolize galactose properly, leading to its accumulation in various tissues, including the lens. This option is also plausible but less common than the accumulation of sorbitol.

 

Option C: Sugar amines are not directly associated with cataract formation. While glycation of lens proteins by sugars can contribute to cataractogenesis, the accumulation of specific sugar amines is not a well-recognized cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Diabetes mellitus, in the lens by polyol pathway, glucose converted to sorbitol by the enzyme Aldose reductase
  • In galactosemia, Dulcitol or Galactitol is responsible for cataract
  • Sorbitol, Dulcitol are sugar alcohols.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p205.

questions.text: Cellulose, a major component of plant cell walls, plays a critical role in providing structural support. Given its biological significance and chemical composition, how is cellulose best categorized?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-starch Polysaccharides.

 

Option C:

 

Cellulose is a non-starch polysaccharide composed of long chains of β-glucose units linked by β(1 → 4) glycosidic bonds. It is a key structural component of the cell wall in plants and is not digestible by humans due to the lack of the necessary enzyme to break down β(1 → 4) bonds.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Cellulose is not a lipoprotein; it does not contain lipid or protein components.

 

Option B: It is not a starch polysaccharide. Starch, another plant polysaccharide, is composed of α-glucose units and serves as an energy storage molecule, whereas cellulose serves a structural role.

 

Option D: Cellulose is not a glycoprotein; it does not contain any protein or covalently bound oligosaccharide chains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Foods contain a variety of other polysaccharides known as nonstarch polysaccharides.
  • They are not digested by human enzymes and form the major components of dietary fibre.
  • E.g.: cellulose from plant cell walls (a glucose polymer) and Inulin, the storage carbohydrate in some plants (a fructose polymer).

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p153.

questions.text: Dextran, a complex branched polysaccharide, has been utilized in various medical applications. One specific use of dextran is in the management of hypovolemia. Based on this application, is it accurate to consider dextran as a plasma volume expander?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) True.

 

Option A:

 

Dextran consists of glucose monomers joined in different Linkages (α 1, 6 and α 1, 4 and α 1, 3). It can be used as Plasma Volume Expander, which are high mol wt. substances that exert colloid osmotic pressure and retain fluid in the vascular component.

 

Substances used are:

 

  • Human albumin
  • Dextran
  • Hydroxyethyl starch (Hetastarch)
  • Degraded gelatine polymer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dextran is indeed used as a plasma volume expander in clinical settings. By increasing the osmotic pressure in the blood vessels, it helps to retain fluid within the circulatory system, thereby expanding plasma volume. This is particularly useful in treating hypovolemia or shock.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e p 79.
